Schizophrenia (for psychosis specifically, but considering other symptoms, it's less likely as a sole diagnosis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including seizures (neurologic involvement), arthropathy (joint pain/inflammation), pericarditis (cardiac inflammation), dyspigmentation (skin changes), and leukopenia (low white blood cell count).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for joint issues, rheumatoid arthritis can have systemic manifestations including pericarditis and, less frequently, leukopenia. Seizures and dyspigmentation are less common.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease that can cause lung problems, skin discoloration (dyspigmentation), and arthropathy. Neurosarcoidosis can cause seizures, and rare cases might involve pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease combines features of several connective tissue diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus, and can present with joint problems, skin changes, neurological symptoms (seizures), pericarditis, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. It can lead to symptoms like arthritic symptoms, skin changes, and, rarely, seizures and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce lupus-like symptoms, including pericarditis, arthropathy, leukopenia, and skin changes. Seizures are less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. It may include dyspigmentation, but seizures and pericarditis are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the glands that produce tears and saliva. However, it can have systemic effects, including arthralgia, and has been associated with leukopenia. Rare cases may involve pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammation of the blood vessels, vasculitis can cause a wide range of symptoms including skin changes, joint pain, and in severe cases, seizures and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: In its late stages, this tick-borne illness can cause arthritis, neurologic symptoms including seizures, and heart problems which could include pericarditis. Dyspigmentation and leukopenia are less commonly associated.

diagnoses: Phrynoderma (a form of follicular hyperkeratosis associated with vitamin deficiencies)

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Common viral infections can lead to symptoms like cough and laryngitis. They may also indirectly affect blood sugar levels and sleep.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition is a form of nerve damage associated with diabetes and can cause hypoglycemia unawareness, dysautonomias, and indirectly lead to sleeping issues.

diagnoses.name: Adrenal Insufficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Adrenal problems can lead to hypoglycemia and dysautonomia, and they might indirectly cause sleep disturbances and increase susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This syndrome can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including sleep disturbances, dysautonomias, and immune system abnormalities that might relate to frequent infections.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.reasoning: GERD can cause cough and laryngitis due to acid reflux. It can interfere with sleep due to discomfort and possibly affect autonomic function.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic inflammatory disease that can cause coughing and might have an impact on sleep quality due to nighttime symptoms. Dysautonomia is a less typical but possible association.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.reasoning: A form of dysautonomia that can cause a wide array of symptoms, including fatigue and potentially influencing blood sugar levels and sleep quality.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause fatigue, affect sleep quality, and potentially lead to a lowered immune response, making one more susceptible to infections like those causing laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Anxiety can indirectly lead to or exacerbate insomnia, dysautonomias, and hypoglycemia due to stress response and potential lifestyle changes.

diagnoses.argumentation: Psychological stress and certain medications used to treat insomnia could potentially worsen or trigger conditions like hypoglycemia.

diagnoses: Voice Strain (due to hyperactivity and possibly Laryngitis as a symptom or cause)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.description: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.details: Chronic inflammation of the sinuses which can affect sleep quality due to difficulty breathing, and may lead to complications such as epistaxis and laryngitis.

diagnoses.description: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.details: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing or periods of shallow breathing during sleep. It can cause non-restorative sleep and exacerbate attention deficit symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.details: A condition where a lack of adequate iron affects the production of hemoglobin, leading to symptoms like fatigue and epistaxis.

diagnoses.description: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.details: An anxiety disorder that can cause difficulty concentrating (attention deficit), sleep disturbances, and physical symptoms, though it's less directly related to endometriosis.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue or tiredness that doesn't improve with rest and worsens with physical or mental activity, potentially linking to non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.description: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.details: A neurodevelopmental disorder that affects both children and adults. It is characterized by problems focusing, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which can impair sleep quality.

diagnoses.description: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.details: Though primarily affecting the ovaries, PCOS can have a systemic effect, including sleep disturbances. Its hormonal imbalances could potentially exacerbate or coincide with symptoms of endometriosis.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.details: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, which affects sleep quality, and menstrual irregularities which might correlate with endometriosis symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.details: An infection that can lead to symptoms like epistaxis, laryngitis, and general fatigue, impacting sleep quality indirectly.

diagnoses.description: Depression
diagnoses.details: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It can lead to a variety of physical and emotional problems and can drastically affect one's sleep, contributing to non-restorative sleep.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the blood vessels. This condition can cause oral ulcers, genital ulcers, skin rashes, and eye inflammation. The symptoms you described can fit into the wide range of manifestations Behçet's disease has.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's disease
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus. Symptoms can include abdominal pain, diarrhea, oral ulcers, and sometimes complications outside the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes and arthritis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus impacts the immune system, leading to a wide range of symptoms as it progresses. Early and chronic stages can include lymphadenitis, oral leukoplakia, and neurological complications that might present as attention deficit. Migratory abdominal pain could be related to gastrointestinal infections secondary to the weakened immune system.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including oral ulcers, skin lesions, neurological manifestations (potentially affecting attention), and abdominal pain due to inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder involving clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells that can lead to a variety of presentations, including skin rashes, bone lesions, lymphadenopathy, and oral manifestations. Abdominal and neurological symptoms can also occur, depending on the extent and location of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause lymphadenitis, and in rare cases, it might present with oral manifestations, abdominal pain, and neurological symptoms like attention deficits due to central nervous system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Reiter's Syndrome (Reactive Arthritis)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that develops in response to an infection. It’s characterized by arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urinary tract symptoms, but can also cause skin and mucosal lesions, including oral ulcers and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection that can present with a wide range of symptoms during its various stages. Primary syphilis typically causes a single sore, but secondary syphilis can lead to skin rashes, oral leukoplakia, and lymphadenopathy. Neurosyphilis can cause symptoms related to attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that occurs in the mucous membranes of the mouth. It can present with leukoplakia, oral pain, and regional lymphadenopathy. Depending on the tumor's location and size, it might also influence other symptoms such as gastrointestinal discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also affect other parts of the body. It can cause lymphadenitis, and in advanced stages, may lead to symptoms resembling attention deficits due to systemic illness. Oral manifestations and abdominal symptoms can also occur in extrapulmonary tuberculosis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, potentially causing a range of symptoms including tinnitus, lymphadenitis, and chemical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms can include frequent waking, chemical sensitivities, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder causing the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. Symptoms include hyperferritinemia and joint pain; it may also indirectly cause symptoms like tinnitus through associated health issues.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, which could present with symptoms such as lymphadenitis and, in some cases, hyperferritinemia due to inflammation or other mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including hyperferritinemia and lymphadenitis due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by its hallmark symptoms - dry eyes and dry mouth. It may also cause chemical sensitivities and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various conditions that can disrupt normal sleep patterns, leading to symptoms such as frequent waking. It may be indirectly related to the patient's other symptoms through effects on overall health.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. It can cause symptoms such as fatigue, which could contribute to frequent waking.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, leading to wide-ranging symptoms including chemical sensitivities, lymphadenitis, and possibly affecting sleep due to generalized discomfort or pain.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A disputed chronic condition characterized by symptoms that the affected person attributes to low-level chemical exposures. Symptoms may include chemical sensitivities, often accompanied by a wide range of nonspecific symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: An ongoing condition characterized by symptoms such as sinus inflammation, nasal congestion, which could explain the congestion and difficulty focusing vision due to pressure.

diagnoses.name: Graves' Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism), which can cause symptoms like difficulty focusing, due to its effect on eye muscles.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: The overproduction of thyroid hormones, which can cause a variety of symptoms including difficulty focusing vision and menstrual irregularities such as dysmenorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms can include menstrual irregularity, excess hair growth, acne, and obesity.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms, including vision problems, sinus-like symptoms due to the trigeminal nerve involvement, and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that causes chronic inflammation of joints and can cause sicca syndrome (dry eyes, dry mouth), which might explain the difficulty focusing vision. It can sometimes affect other tissues throughout the body and cause various symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues, also reported complications with menstrual irregularities.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues, which might cause fatigue contributing to difficulty focusing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue may worsen with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus — the endometrium — grows outside your uterus. It can cause severe dysmenorrhea and fertility problems.

diagnoses: Sexually Transmitted Infections causing vaginitis (e.g., Chlamydia, Gonorrhea)

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur suddenly and affect the whole body. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, hypotension, angioedema, sneezing, and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder characterized by sudden and recurrent episodes of swelling (angioedema). Patients may also experience abdominal cramps, hypotension, and syncope, but sneezing is not typically associated.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells, leading to a release of mediators that can cause a variety of symptoms including abdominal cramps, hypotension, angioedema, and potentially syncope.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting (syncope) that can be triggered by various stimuli, including severe pain from abdominal cramps. It is often accompanied by hypotension but not typically angioedema or sneezing.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An adverse health effect arising from a specific immune response that occurs reproducibly on exposure to a given food. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, hypotension, angioedema, sneezing, and syncope.

diagnoses.name: Drug Hypersensitivity Reaction
diagnoses.description: An adverse reaction to a medication that can manifest as various symptoms, including abdominal cramps, hypotension, angioedema, and syncope. Sneezing is less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections, characterized by hypotension, rash, and multi-organ involvement. Syncope, abdominal cramps, and sometimes angioedema can be present.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of their hormones. Symptoms can include abdominal cramps, hypotension, and in some cases, syncope. Angioedema and sneezing are not typical.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Capillary Leak Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder characterized by acute episodes of severe hypotension, hemoconcentration, and generalized edema, including angioedema. Abdominal cramps and syncope can occur, but sneezing is not a common symptom.

diagnoses.name: Peanut Allergy
diagnoses.description: A type of food allergy specific to peanuts, where ingestion can lead to symptoms including abdominal cramps, hypotension, angioedema, sneezing, and syncope.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
Venom allergy (e.g., bee or wasp stings)
Allergic Rhinitis (with associated anaphylaxis or food allergy)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain accompanied by visual disturbances, numbness, and sometimes vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain can cause headaches, nausea, vomiting, changes in hearing, and numbness or weakness of part of the body.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Neuronitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the vestibular nerve causing vertigo, hearing loss, and sometimes nausea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves, causing numbness, weakness, balance issues, and potentially, issues with hearing.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A noncancerous growth on the vestibulocochlear nerve affecting balance and hearing.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, symptoms can include headache, numbness, and issues with vision, though hearing loss is less common.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, causing severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and sometimes hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted, causing brain tissue damage. Symptoms can include headache, numbness, difficulty speaking, and rarely, hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, often in the head, causing severe headaches, vision problems, jaw pain, and sometimes symptoms affecting the ears like hearing loss.

diagnoses: Migraine (particularly basilar-type or with brainstem aura)
Ménière's disease (for vertigo and nausea, less commonly associated with aphasia)
Epilepsy (postictal state or related to focal seizure activity)

diagnoses.description: A chronic disease of the central nervous system marked by damage to the myelin sheath. It can cause symptoms such as weakness, hearing loss, and dysarthria.
A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. It might also lead to nausea and balance issues.
A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. It can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms depending on its location.
Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted, depriving brain tissue of oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include dysarthria and weakness.
A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Nausea, phonophobia, and aura are common.
A progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness and dysarthria.
A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Hearing loss is a common symptom.
An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including neurological manifestations.
A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis.
A condition resulting from restricted blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include vertigo, dysarthria, and other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with Associated Felty's Syndrome
Secondary Antiphospholipid Syndrome (associated with another autoimmune condition)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with Immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including maculopapular rash, proteinuria due to kidney involvement, nonscarring alopecia, and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Though more commonly associated with muscle weakness and a heliotrope rash, dermatomyositis can occasionally present with features similar to those listed, particularly in overlap syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: MCTD can feature symptoms including nonscarring alopecia and hemolytic anemia. Though less common, skin and kidney involvement presenting as rash and proteinuria can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Primarily affects the exocrine glands but can have systemic manifestations including skin rashes and hemolytic anemia. Nonscarring alopecia and renal involvement (proteinuria) can be part of its presentation.

diagnoses.name: Lupus-like Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: A drug-induced condition mimicking many of the systemic and skin manifestations of SLE including rash, proteinuria, and potentially alopecia and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: While primarily affecting the joints, RA can have systemic manifestations including skin rashes and, more rarely, hemolytic anemia and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Syphilis
diagnoses.reason: Can present with a maculopapular rash, generalized lymphadenopathy, and potentially hemolytic anemia. Proteinuria might be present in the context of nephropathy.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP)
diagnoses.reason: Primarily pediatric but can occur in adults; presents with a characteristic rash (often purpuric rather than maculopapular), renal involvement (proteinuria), and can have systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Foliaceus
diagnoses.reason: An autoimmune blistering disorder that can involve alopecia and skin rashes, though it is less commonly associated with hemolytic anemia or kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.reason: Chronic hepatitis C infection can be associated with extrahepatic manifestations including lichen planus, mixed cryoglobulinemia (which can present with a maculopapular rash and proteinuria), and hemolytic anemia.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis)
